awd_titl_txt: Developing a Climatology of Horizontal Convective Rolls over Oklahoma:  Combining Observational Data Sets to Increase Understanding
awd_abstract_narration:
Horizontal convective rolls (HCRs) are a common occurrence in the warm season and influence planetary boundary layer (PBL) mixing, PBL structure and convection initiation. Yet very little is known about the climatology of HCRs. This oversight is worrisome as HCRs are present in convection-allowing models and studies suggest that these modeled HCRs can be caused by inaccuracies in PBL parameterization. The goal of the research is to use the Twin Lakes, Oklahoma (KTLX), WSR-88D to observe HCRs during the warm season and merge this information with ancillary data to develop a rich, multi-year data base for studying HCRs.  From the KTLX observations we will pursue the following scientific objectives: 1) Develop a 10-year warm season climatology of HCR occurrence frequency and characteristics (time of onset and decay, wavelength, orientation angle, year-to-year variability) using observations from April to September 2005-2014; 2) Determine PBL depth and mean PBL winds and wind shear using Rapid Update Cycle (RUC) or Rapid Refresh (RAP) analyses, and hence calculate HCR aspect ratios, for each day with HCRs; 3) Use Oklahoma Mesonet observations from three surface stations underneath the KTLX clear-air radar volume to calculate sensible heat flux and other surface parameters associated with HCR formation and maintenance; 4) Test and identify a robust automated approach to HCR identification that could then be used in a subsequent studies to extend the HCR climatology nationally using all available WSR-88D observation locations. The resulting large data set on HCRs will then be used to examine the mechanisms of HCR formation and help improve our understanding of this common boundary layer phenomenon.

Intellectual Merit:
The created HCR data set will be novel in terms of the number of cases (several hundred) and the richness of the ancillary environmental data on surface fluxes and PBL structure, and will be used to define the warm season HCR frequency, aspect ratios, orientation angles, typical onset time and longevity for the first time ever. These data will be incredibly beneficial to compare with the frequency of HCR formation in convection-allowing numerical weather prediction models. This type of comparison will help determine how well PBL schemes function as horizontal grid spacing continues to decrease below 3 km.

Broader Impacts:
The project will enhance graduate, undergraduate, and precollege education, including the mentoring of a graduate student, graduate student participation in development of inquiry-based activities for undergraduate meteorology courses, and implementation of a week-long K-12 teacher workshop using adaptations of these activities followed by academic year support for K-12 classroom implementation. This will lead to enhanced K-12 teachers' and students' understanding of research strategies utilizing radar data to study mesoscale atmospheric phenomena and will increase graduate students' and K-12 teachers' understanding of the systems thinking involved in meteorological research, while also enhancing researchers' and graduate students' understanding of inquiry-based teaching practices and communication skills with non-technical audiences.

por.por_cntn:
Our lives are spent in the boundary layer, the layer of the atmosphere that interacts strongly with the land surface and extends vertically to depths of around 1 km above ground level during the daytime hours.  This layer tends to be turbulent during the daytime, although when viewed from above the boundary layer has two common flow patterns that can be discerned from weather radar observations.  One pattern consists of long parallel lines of upward motion that are seen as lines of larger radar reflectivity values (Image 1a), with sinking motion in between the lines.  If clouds develop at the top of the boundary layer, then this flow pattern results in parallel bands of clouds called cloud streets.  The second pattern consists of circular regions of upward motion that are seen as circular or hexagonal shapes in larger values of radar reflectivity that are adjacent to one another (Image 1b).  These two flow patterns strongly influence the movement of heat, moisture, pollution, and winds within the boundary layer.

We have known about these two boundary-layer organizational patterns for many years, although our knowledge of how often they form and how long they persist was limited.  In this project, we examined weather radar observations from central Oklahoma for 10 years during the warm season (April to September) and learned that these patterns are present on over 92% of days without precipitation.  They often form in midmorning and dissipate around sunset.  Analyses further indicate that the long parallel lines often are oriented within 10 degrees of the mean boundary layer wind, in agreement with earlier studies.  The organizational patterns can shift during the daytime, changing from linear to circular patterns or vice versa.  Days with shifting organization patterns happen on roughly one third of the days studied.  In total, these organizational patterns are present for 34% of the daylight hours during the warm season. 

We further collected observations from Doppler weather radars and surface weather stations to evaluate whether one could accurately predict the formation of linear or circular patterns on a given day.  Results indicate that one can predict which pattern will form with 72% accuracy using routinely available weather observations.  A mean boundary layer wind speed of 6 m s-1 is a good discriminator, with lines most likely to occur for wind speeds above this value. 

During the radar data analysis phase of this research project, it was noticed that dual-polarization weather radars were able to sense the top of the daytime boundary layer.  Building upon the work of others, we documented that dual-polarization weather radars can observe the top of the daytime boundary layer with reasonable accuracy.  This happens because Bragg scatter occurs at the top of the daytime boundary layer and produces a minimum value in the vertical profile of radar differential reflectivity.  A simple technique was used that calculates the mean observed value of differential reflectivity for all azimuth angles (0 to 360 degrees) for each range gate and then converts distance away from the radar to height above ground level.  This approach allows one to track the top of the boundary layer, which typically increases during the morning hours and reaches a maximum value for the day in the early afternoon (Image 2). 

The radar observation of boundary layer depth is a particularly exciting outcome of this project.  It should be very beneficial for future weather prediction activities and could be calculated every 10 minutes or so from the dual-polarization radar network in the United States.  This radar observation opens new avenues for boundary layer research and operational weather forecasting. 

This project conducted a K12 STEM teacher workshop one summer to enhance teacher knowledge of the atmospheric boundary layer and weather radar, thereby providing an avenue to bring more weather content into the classroom.  Two graduate students were supported by this grant and both received mentoring and training in atmospheric sciences, with results presented at scientific conferences.  Both graduate students received their Master of Science degrees in Meteorology and Atmospheric Science.  An undergraduate student assisted in the research and subsequently attended graduate school.  Project results also were published in the peer-reviewed literature.
